Matt,
I think that Graham is talking about putting the final texture on the guard.  The forging and shaping of the plate would be done with a normal hammer.  Some iron guards are indeed finished with an array of tiny pock marks like he describes.  It's more likely that this was done with a small punch that was struck with a hammer rather than directly with a pin-headed hammer.  It'd be a lot easier to place and control the punch, and quicker to make and maintain the tool.  But, I wasn't there to see it done.

Most Ko-Katchushi don't show this, BTW.  If they ever had it the traces have rusted away.  It's easier to find on some later work.
Jim


  Gang I am reading Graham Gemmells book 'Tosogu, treasure of the samurai'
  where he discusses an early - mid Muromachi ko-katchushi tsuba and
  mentions that a hammer nearly the size of a pin head was used to work
  (and fold?) the steel, and thus create the textures in the iron that
  make these things so pleasing to look at. I have some real trouble
  imagining this being done. I presume he is talking about a hammer a bit
  like an ice-pick with a very small surface that actually strikes the
  metal? Why not just use a big one like the sword smith?

  - Matt
